author: MGDawson
title: The camping line continues!
review:
The last time I brought something relating to camping from Lego was the Camper (7639) from 2009. How does this iteration hold up?

Box/Instructions

The box was extremely compact as per most sets of late, with little air space in the box. With the removal of the van's mirrors, both items fit in the box easily.

The instructions (two books, one per vehicle) were easy to follow with no issues. 

Parts

Nothing really stood out for me as being rare or unique parts wise, except for maybe the colouring of some parts. 

Minifigures

The figures presented are a nice variation to standard fare, especially the female figure, whos hairpiece and torso stand her out from other figures in the city line.

While in this section, I should mention the doggy - who even comes with his own bone to chew. Or maybe it's hoping to steal one of the sausages?

The build

The build went together easily and quickly, with no major issues (except when I forgot to put a piece in the van).

The completed model

There are a few niggles with the design, IMHO. Nothing to stop you buying the set per se, but issues I found distracting.

First, there is the area around the front bumper of the van. The front indicators should really be cheese slopes to match the headlights, it seems strange to utilize the 1x1 plates for this. The gap behind the bumper and the front wheels seems odd too, which unfortunately is only fixable if the bonnet is brought forward a stud.

Second, the caravan. There's a bed, and a coffee machine. No sink, cookware or other facilities are available - including toilets! There's also no TV or other facilities so the 'figs must either have bad hygiene or they're only out in their caravan temporarily. Speaking of the bed, good luck trying to get both figs in properly and lying down, it's only 4 wide and the walls are solid bricks, not recessed panels.

The caravan also seems to be inspired by/is based on 4435's caravan. Not necessarily a bad thing, but considering they're supposed to be different makes...

Also the choice of a 1x1 round tile in grey for the roof where the side moves over to attach to seems weird. Why not use a 1x1 smooth tile?

Bad points out the way, what about the positives?

The van has capacity for both figures AND their dog, plus any luggage (no suitcases included, except for the stove, sausages and dog bone).

The van is unlike most of the vehicles in city, and both it and the caravan have excellent proportions - no wheels stick out and everything is to scale with each other. The removable ceiling/roof and side panel are excellently executed, and there's plenty of room for people like me to get my hands in to place figures in properly.

Overall opinion

As one of only two sets that I've been interested in this year from the City line, I am definitely pleased with my purchase, though I'll be looking to upgrade/modify the caravan at a later date with more features (especially a toilet and washbasin!)

author: turtlestack
title: Wonderful compliment to the Lakeside Lodge set
review:
I bought this set to compliment the 31048: Lakeside Lodge and they work together very well. The set uses fun, bright, primary colors, has a few nice details (the grill, and the dog), and is a very good looking design for both the van and the camper. I especially like the camper with its foldout door, though it does lack some interior detail. However, this is a value set (I paid only $20 at Target US) and for the money the set has a lot of playability.

Very easy to put together (in fact this was probably the easiest set I've every assembled), looks great, and compliments other LEGO sets very nicely.

author: Sobel
title: Another great camping mobile!
review:
First off, I have been a friend of camping and caravaning my whole life! So it was clear, I had to buy the 60057 Camper Van last year, and now this little beauty also immediately caught my attention. So I sneaked it in the online shopping cart while buying some minifigures for my daughter when my wife wasn't looking! ;-)

Box/Instructions

It's a standard-sized LEGO box. Always nice to hold in hands when new, shiny and sealed!

Parts

Nothing spectacular here. Just the typical parts for LEGO vehicles like tires, windows, mudguards and so on. You get a bone for the dog and some coffee and sausages (must be Brits) for the LEGO people.

Minifigures

No surprises here either. Basic, fitting perfectly into the image of peace-seeking caravaners. A guy, a girl and their dog on a peaceful vacation! What could be more relaxing?

The build

Due to the rather small number of parts and the simple instructions, the build holds no challenge. It's very straightforward, building both the van and the trailer from bottom to the top.

The completed model

The van is a sturdy vehicle wih big windows in the back, so the passengers can marvel at the countryside. It even has a special place to put the dog in, so it doesn't go loose in the car (OK, moves a bit from left to right, oh welllll...).
The trailer has a bed (just like the 60057 model), a place to sit down, a coffee machine and a cup holder. Additionally, the set features a barbecue grill with "glowing coal" and two sausages. I think there should have been a better solution for where to put the grill while driving, but well, I guess you can't have everything, no?
The trailer has a big hatch you can open to the side, so you can access the interior and place the minifigures.

Overall opinion

Oh, the details! I love them!! A coffee machine! A barbecue grill! The cuddly interior of the trailer! This set has everything an old camper would need! There no great functions, but hey, if you have imagination, there are infinite holidays waiting for you!
And who wouldn't like to go camping with friends? So go and grab the 60057 Camping Caravan, too!!

author: andyh1984
title: All-round nice set
review:
I bought this on an impulse in the toyshop as I am going to get 31052 Vacation Getaways and thought they will go well together.

Box/Instructions

Standard city box showing model and play features

Parts

Lots of blue and white parts and tinted windows

Minifigures

 A male in a dark blue square pattern shirt with red lines and grey trousers, and a female with a green jacket over a pale blue top with light tan trousers, she has the hairpiece which any Lego Star Wars collectors will recognise from Obi-Wan Kenobi in 75021 Republic Gunship, This is the first time I have had a female with this hairpiece and it looks different. There is also a brown dog with dark brown and black printing on his muzzle/snout/nose.

The build

Essentially 2 builds the grill/bbq and the car are built first and it is a larger off-road type vehicle but with normal wheels and ground clearance. The caravan has a hinged section so you can get inside.

The completed model

The car unusually fits 2 minifigures (one behind the other) and the dog, I was expecting one fig and the dog to have to travel in the caravan and probably this is the reason for the larger car. The caravan is outfitted with a bed and a coffee machine, and the grill can be stored on the roof, a 1x2 tile with a lip (probably not the actual piece name) on the edge of the roof stops the hinged section from opening.

 

Overall opinion

I really like this set, it has playability and will fit into a city street theme or an outdoors theme.

author: danbailey
title: Good Family Fun
review:
This is one of the more fun kits I've purchased for myself.  Lately, I've been focused on bigger sets and chasing down Series 16 minifigs, but with this on sale at Target, the price was right and I went for it.

Box/Instructions

As an AFOL who'd been out of the hobby since the mid-1990's (I was an AFOL then, too), one of the things I've had issues with since returning to the hobby in 2015 is the multiple instruction books, and all the **** stickers.  This kit has two books, which I'm okay with -- it's split in such a way that book one covers the SUV and the grill, and book two is for the trailer.  Fortunately, there's not a ton of stickers in this set, like there are in others (I'm looking at you, Avengers Tower).

Parts

Great assortment.  I feel like I could build multiple varieties of cars or different campers out of the pieces included, as there's a great mix of structural pieces and smaller/automotive pieces.  I don't get this feeling with some other sets I've purchase, like the Speed Champions series.  

Minifigures

They look like they just walked out of an REI.

The build

Fun!  Simple enough where I was able to collaborate with it on my four year-old and he didn't have any problem following along, but I wasn't bored, either.  With the multi-stage build, we were able to hand the SUV to his little brother (two and a half) to play with while we built the trailer together.

The completed model

I like it!  It'll probably end up doing some time on my desk at the office.  My kids love it, and as our only point of friction during the whole thing, they argued over who got to play with it before bed time.  (Hint: both of you do, stop fighting.)  

That said, there's room for both people in each vehicle, the coffeepot in the trailer is a really nice touch, and I liked the storage for the grill inside the SUV.  Little details like the hot coals (trans orange 1x1 round tiles) really made the model.

Overall opinion

Definitely worth spending the money on.  If you're a big fan of City, this is a should-have.

author: lentil
title: Great little set for the money!
review:
I think this set is a great example of what LEGO can do with a good designer and relatively small number of essentially simple bricks. Classic LEGO excellence!

The set contains two vehicles: a towing vehicle (van) and a camper-trailer (caravan). The design of both is quite nice - the van looks like a rugged off-roader in bright blue with grey stripes, is nicely tiled giving it a smooth but chunky shape, and has well-placed, simple details like trans elements representing lights, and 1x1 plates for rear-view mirrors. The camper has a snazzy retro look with its green horizontal stripe at the base and goofy mountain stickers. I'm a big sucker for those smoky tinted windows and this set has them in spades - especially love the giant windows on either side of the camper which give a good view of the interior (not much privacy for those attempting to nap in there though!). There are a total of 3 tinted windshields, 6 small windows, and 2 large ones in the set altogether which is a pretty good haul for a small set.

The doors of the van open, although it is difficult to get the figs through this opening which is a bit narrow. Fortunately the roof panels are easy to remove and the back of the van is quite roomy for multiple passengers and/or cargo. I especially like how one side of the camper swings open to reveal complete access to the interior. This is a great play feature! The camper is pretty small inside and does not have too many details (bed, seat, coffee maker), but again for the small amount a bricks involved this is an ingenious little number.

It comes with only two minifigs and a dog, but room enough inside for additional friends and neighbors to go along for the ride if you so choose.

My 10-year old daughter enjoys this set and uses it to transport the inhabitants of her LEGO world back and forth from their city houses to their vacation homes, such as the Lakeside Lodge and Seaside House. It makes a perfect companion to the Creator houses despite being in the City line.

Overall I think this little set is a hidden gem and consider it incredible value for the money, even at full/regular price - if discounted it of course becomes a downright steal! It's one thing to create a wonderful set using a 4000 piece count, 32 colors, and all sorts of different pieces... another ball game entirely to come up with something good in a small package and low price point, with just simple parts and techniques. Kudos to LEGO for producing great sets in a variety of ranges.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Fun Outdoor Adventurers
review:
Set #60117 Van & Caravan: I’m a sucker for these camping themed vehicles from LEGO City. I’m not entirely sure why, personally I can’t stand the pastime, but in LEGO City they manage to show off the fun and draw of the activity without making anything look frustrating or gloomy.

This set from LEGO City is a fairly impressive one, read on for my thoughts on the set, unfortunately I can’t compare it with any other versions as I didn’t get the earlier interpretation of this set they made.

Box/Instructions

Box: Your standard looking LEGO City box design, which hasn’t changed very much since its inception. This one shows off the set very nicely and all of the features in the back. Great functional box design.

Instructions: The three numbered bags in this set are broken up between two numbered manuals, giving you one manual for each half of the vehicles found in this set. With manual number one you get the step-by-step instructions for the van and with manual number two you receive the steps for the caravan.

They are standard for LEGO City manuals, with few cross-promotional images and no Minifigure checklists as LEGO City has far too many offerings for such a thing. The front of each manual shows a nice little picture of the finished model photoshopped into a small forested area near a large city. Great to show off everything in the set.

Parts

Not too much to discuss in this section. It’s a box full of fairly standard parts, there are no rare elements or parts to keep an eye out for where MOC fans are concerned. But there is a relatively large selection of blue pieces for the Van vehicle, a nice rich dark blue that is a rare sight colour wise these days.

Minifigures

Male Camper: Like with most LEGO City sets there’s really not much to say about the Minifigures. You’ll find standard prints and standard parts on both figures here. They also don’t have any accessories. So yeah, single-sided dark blue torso with checkered shirt print, standard smiling facial print and dark brown hair piece.

Female Camper: Double-sided torso print with green jacket and white undershirt, includes a pendant on a chain. Single sided smiling face found on most Female characters, light orange Dastan hair piece for a short haired look. Relatively nice look figure combination, standard parts from LEGO though as I said before.

The build

Bag 1: The van’s undercarriage is begun with this bag, once the Minifigures are finished they can get to work building their brand new LEGO Van & Caravan that will take them to the camping site. LEGO City sets rarely involve any difficult steps, so there should be no trouble here.

Bag 2: With this bag you complete the Van. And I must say this is a very satisfying little vehicle build. Again it’s fairly standard where LEGO City sets are concerned, however it’s always nice to get ordinary vehicles to populate your display and these sets rarely disappoint. Some stickers for detailing the license plate and such are included, these shouldn’t pose too much of a problem.

Bag 3: The Caravan is all you’re building here, that cute little barbecue was built back in bag 1, so you get to construct a very nice looking trailer for your campers to use. There’s nothing truly difficult in this particular build, you’ll have a few minor sticker placements to keep in mind, but again they aren’t on tricky pieces to apply them to so they should be relatively simple to apply.

The completed model

Van: This model stands out to me as being a nice little Mini-Van. It’s not a full on van, but it does resemble the vehicle in question more than a Van. But I digress. You can fit everybody inside, there’s space for two Minifigures and one canine companion in the back. The colour scheme really pops on this model and I love the look of it. Not much more to say here, as the play features are all located in the second portion of the build.

Caravan: This is a great looking model, a trailer camping vehicle, aka Caravan, features some nice detailing for the interior and is great for a family of two. Popping off the locking piece and flipping open the vehicle in question gives you access to inside where you’ll find a place to sit, a bed to lie down on, two coffee mugs and a fancy looking coffee maker model.

You can fit the barbecue with the two hot dogs on top. So everything can store together. There really isn’t any fancy play features like you’d find with other Themes, but honestly that isn’t a big loss. The display options and play options for folks are great enough for a set like this.

The dog included is a standard LEGO dog, first introduced with the Arctic sub-theme. He has a bit of facial printing and gets to gnaw on a bone included with him.

Overall opinion

When it comes to these style of LEGO City sets at the 25$ price point you rarely go wrong when picking them up. I got mine at Costco for a much cheaper price, and so I can really strongly recommend this. It’s a fun looking pair of vehicles which can be quite satisfying to build and play with. They make great additional vehicles to display alongside other sets of a camping Theme, such as the LEGO Creator cabin set from a few years ago, or the new larger RV inspired set. I strongly recommend this set for all LEGO City and Great Vehicles fans.

author: FlyRobinFly03
title: Great Caravan
review:
Minifigures- There just common minifigures, so nothing too special.

Parts- I don't how common the dog is, but its a cheap alternative than buying a police station. The sausages are great pieces. 

Builds- The car is pretty mediocre, but still pretty cool. The caravan is probably the best build, since we don't get too many trailers.

Overall- I think this a good little set for adults. I don't think kids would like this because its just a car and trailer and no play features except for the side opening door.

author: ShawnMarie
title: Love the Caravan - and the dog
review:
We picked this set up unopened as part of a lot off Facebook Marketplace.... paid $7 for it and it was totally worth that price.  My 8 year old daughter put it together in about an hour and a half.  She had a little trouble with the van but no issues with the caravan.

We love the fact that the caravan opens, we love the smoothie maker, we love the hotdog grill! 

This is exactly the kind of set I enjoy as a AFOL.  Fun to build, lots of unique pieces and fits in well with other sets.

author: JDJohnson
title: I loved It So Much
review: this is a good set i like the little coffee pot and The two mugs for the boy and the girl you can attach the grill to the headlights to make it look cool i like the doggie it has a new print the doggie has a bone i like the tan sides with the blue the camper is cute too
